title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others‚Äô private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement lucydagostino@gmail.com. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.0, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/0/code_of_conduct.html. code: install.packages("tipr") # install.packages(devtools) devtools::install_github("lucymcgowan/tipr") library(tipr)

title: Tipping Point Analyses
text: fitting model, can determine unmeasured confounder needed tip analysis. unmeasured confounder determined two quantities, relationship exposure unmeasured confounder (unmeasured confounder continuous, indicated exposure_confounder_effect, binary, exposed_confounder_prev unexposed_confounder_prev), relationship unmeasured confounder outcome confounder_outcome_effect. Using üì¶, can fix one solve . Alternatively, can fix solve n, , many unmeasured confounders magnitude tip analysis. example, model fit exposure-outcome relationship 1.5 (95% CI: 1.2, 1.8).

title: Tipping Point Analyses
text: interested continuous unmeasured confounder, use tip_with_continuous() function. package comes example data set simulated scenario, exdata_continuous. Let‚Äôs assume relationship unmeasured confounder outcome 1.5 (confounder_outcome_effect = 1.5), let‚Äôs solve relationship exposure unmeasured confounder needed tip analysis (case, solving exposure_confounder_effect, mean difference needed exposed unexposed). hypothetical unobserved continuous confounder relationship 1.5 outcome need scaled mean difference exposure groups 0.45 tip analysis 5% level, rendering inconclusive.
code: tip(effect_observed = 1.2, confounder_outcome_effect = 1.5) ## The observed effect (1.2) WOULD be tipped by 1 unmeasured confounder ## with the following specifications: ##   * estimated difference in scaled means between the unmeasured confounder ##     in the exposed population and unexposed population: 0.45 ##   * estimated relationship between the unmeasured confounder and the outcome: 1.5  ## # A tibble: 1 √ó 5 ##   effect_adjusted effect_observed exposure_confounder_effect confounder_outcome‚Ä¶ ##             <dbl>           <dbl>                      <dbl>               <dbl> ## 1               1             1.2                      0.450                 1.5 ## # ‚Ä¶ with 1 more variable: n_unmeasured_confounders <dbl>

title: Tipping Point Analyses
text: Now interested binary unmeasured confounder, use tip_with_binary() function. Let‚Äôs assume unmeasured confounder prevalent 25% exposed population (exposed_confounder_prev = 0.25) 10% unexposed population (unexposed_confounder_prev = 0.10) ‚Äì let‚Äôs solve relationship unmeasured confounder outcome needed tip analysis (confounder_outcome_effect). hypothetical unobserved binary confounder prevalent 10% unexposed population 25% exposed population need relationship outcome 2.5 tip analysis 5% level, rendering inconclusive.
code: tip_with_binary(effect_observed = 1.2,                  exposed_confounder_prev = 0.25,                  unexposed_confounder_prev = 0.10) ## The observed effect (1.2) WOULD be tipped by 1 unmeasured confounder ## with the following specifications: ##   * estimated prevalence of the unmeasured confounder in the exposed population: 0.25 ##   * estimated prevalence of the unmeasured confounder in the unexposed population: 0.1 ##   * estimated relationship between the unmeasured confounder and the outcome: 2.54  ## # A tibble: 1 √ó 6 ##   effect_adjusted effect_observed exposed_confounder_prev unexposed_confounder_‚Ä¶ ##             <dbl>           <dbl>                   <dbl>                  <dbl> ## 1               1             1.2                    0.25                    0.1 ## # ‚Ä¶ with 2 more variables: confounder_outcome_effect <dbl>, ## #   n_unmeasured_confounders <dbl>

title: Tipping Point Analyses
text: Suppose concerned many small, independent, continuous, unmeasured confounders present. take 15 independent standardized Normal unmeasured confounders mean difference exposure groups 0.25 relationship outcome 1.05 tip observed analysis 5% level, rendering inconclusive.
code: tip(effect_observed = 1.2,      exposure_confounder_effect = 0.25,      confounder_outcome_effect = 1.05) ## The observed effect (1.2) WOULD be tipped by 15 unmeasured confounders ## with the following specifications: ##   * estimated difference in scaled means between the unmeasured confounder ##     in the exposed population and unexposed population: 0.25 ##   * estimated relationship between the unmeasured confounder and the outcome: 1.05  ## # A tibble: 1 √ó 5 ##   effect_adjusted effect_observed exposure_confounder_effect confounder_outcome‚Ä¶ ##             <dbl>           <dbl>                      <dbl>               <dbl> ## 1               1             1.2                       0.25                1.05 ## # ‚Ä¶ with 1 more variable: n_unmeasured_confounders <dbl>

title: Tipping Point Analyses
text: functions created easily integrate models tidied using broom package. necessary use functions, nice feature choose . example logistic regression fit glm tidied tidy function broom can directly fed tip() function.
code: if (requireNamespace("broom", quietly = TRUE) &&  requireNamespace("dplyr", quietly = TRUE)) {    glm(am ~ mpg, data = mtcars, family = "binomial") %>%     broom::tidy(conf.int = TRUE, exponentiate = TRUE) %>%     dplyr::filter(term == "mpg") %>%     dplyr::pull(conf.low) %>%     tip(confounder_outcome_effect = 2.5) } ## The observed effect (1.13) WOULD be tipped by 1 unmeasured confounder ## with the following specifications: ##   * estimated difference in scaled means between the unmeasured confounder ##     in the exposed population and unexposed population: 0.13 ##   * estimated relationship between the unmeasured confounder and the outcome: 2.5  ## # A tibble: 1 √ó 5 ##   effect_adjusted effect_observed exposure_confounder_effect confounder_outcome‚Ä¶ ##             <dbl>           <dbl>                      <dbl>               <dbl> ## 1               1            1.13                      0.133                 2.5 ## # ‚Ä¶ with 1 more variable: n_unmeasured_confounders <dbl>

Often models estimated intercept N - k - 1 k number predictors model. confounder_exposure_r2 Numeric value 0 1. assumed partial R2 unobserved confounder exposure given measured covariates. confounder_outcome_r2 Numeric value 0 1. assumed partial R2 unobserved confounder outcome given exposure measured covariates. verbose Logical. Indicates whether print informative message. Default: TRUE alpha Significance level. Default = 0.05. ... Optional arguments passed sensemakr::adjusted_estimate() function.

title: Tip a result with a normally distributed confounder. ‚Äî tip
code: ## to estimate the relationship between an unmeasured confounder and outcome ## needed to tip analysis tip(1.2, exposure_confounder_effect = -2) #> The observed effect (1.2) WOULD be tipped by 1 unmeasured confounder #> with the following specifications: #>   * estimated difference in scaled means between the unmeasured confounder #>     in the exposed population and unexposed population: -2 #>   * estimated relationship between the unmeasured confounder and the outcome: 0.91 #>  #> # A tibble: 1 √ó 5 #>   effect_adjusted effect_observed exposure_confounder_effect confounde‚Ä¶¬π n_unm‚Ä¶¬≤ #>             <dbl>           <dbl>                      <dbl>       <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1               1             1.2                         -2       0.913       1 #> # ‚Ä¶ with abbreviated variable names ¬π‚Äãconfounder_outcome_effect, #> #   ¬≤‚Äãn_unmeasured_confounders  ## to estimate the number of unmeasured confounders specified needed to tip ## the analysis tip(1.2, exposure_confounder_effect = -2, confounder_outcome_effect = .99) #> The observed effect (1.2) WOULD be tipped by 9 unmeasured confounders #> with the following specifications: #>   * estimated difference in scaled means between the unmeasured confounder #>     in the exposed population and unexposed population: -2 #>   * estimated relationship between the unmeasured confounder and the outcome: 0.99 #>  #> # A tibble: 1 √ó 5 #>   effect_adjusted effect_observed exposure_confounder_effect confounde‚Ä¶¬π n_unm‚Ä¶¬≤ #>             <dbl>           <dbl>                      <dbl>       <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1               1             1.2                         -2        0.99    9.07 #> # ‚Ä¶ with abbreviated variable names ¬π‚Äãconfounder_outcome_effect, #> #   ¬≤‚Äãn_unmeasured_confounders  ## Example with broom if (requireNamespace("broom", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("dplyr", quietly = TRUE)) {   glm(am ~ mpg, data = mtcars, family = "binomial") %>%    broom::tidy(conf.int = TRUE, exponentiate = TRUE) %>%    dplyr::filter(term == "mpg") %>%    dplyr::pull(conf.low) %>%    tip(confounder_outcome_effect = 2.5) } #> The observed effect (1.13) WOULD be tipped by 1 unmeasured confounder #> with the following specifications: #>   * estimated difference in scaled means between the unmeasured confounder #>     in the exposed population and unexposed population: 0.13 #>   * estimated relationship between the unmeasured confounder and the outcome: 2.5 #>  #> # A tibble: 1 √ó 5 #>   effect_adjusted effect_observed exposure_confounder_effect confounde‚Ä¶¬π n_unm‚Ä¶¬≤ #>             <dbl>           <dbl>                      <dbl>       <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1               1            1.13                      0.133         2.5       1 #> # ‚Ä¶ with abbreviated variable names ¬π‚Äãconfounder_outcome_effect, #> #   ¬≤‚Äãn_unmeasured_confounders

to estimate the number of unmeasured confounders specified needed to tip ## the analysis tip_or(1.2, exposure_confounder_effect = -2, confounder_outcome_effect = .99) #> The observed effect (1.2) WOULD be tipped by 9 unmeasured confounders #> with the following specifications: #>   * estimated difference in scaled means between the unmeasured confounder #>     in the exposed population and unexposed population: -2 #>   * estimated relationship between the unmeasured confounder and the outcome: 0.99 #>  #> # A tibble: 1 √ó 5 #>   effect_adjusted effect_observed exposure_confounder_effect confounde‚Ä¶¬π n_unm‚Ä¶¬≤ #>             <dbl>           <dbl>                      <dbl>       <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1               1             1.2                         -2        0.99    9.07 #> # ‚Ä¶ with abbreviated variable names ¬π‚Äãconfounder_outcome_effect, #> #   ¬≤‚Äãn_unmeasured_confounders  ## Example with broom if (requireNamespace("broom", quietly = TRUE) &&     requireNamespace("dplyr", quietly = TRUE)) {   glm(am ~ mpg, data = mtcars, family = "binomial") %>%    broom::tidy(conf.int = TRUE, exponentiate = TRUE) %>%    dplyr::filter(term == "mpg") %>%    dplyr::pull(conf.low) %>%    tip_or(confounder_outcome_effect = 2.5, or_correction = TRUE) } #> The observed effect (1.06) WOULD be tipped by 1 unmeasured confounder #> with the following specifications: #>   * estimated difference in scaled means between the unmeasured confounder #>     in the exposed population and unexposed population: 0.13 #>   * estimated relationship between the unmeasured confounder and the outcome: 1.58 #>  #> You opted to use the odds ratio correction to convert your odds ratios to approximate risk ratios. #> This is a good idea if the outcome is common (>15%). #> # A tibble: 1 √ó 5 #>   effect_adjusted effect_observed exposure_confounder_effect confounde‚Ä¶¬π n_unm‚Ä¶¬≤ #>             <dbl>           <dbl>                      <dbl>       <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1               1            1.06                      0.133        1.58       1 #> # ‚Ä¶ with abbreviated variable names ¬π‚Äãconfounder_outcome_effect, #> #   ¬≤‚Äãn_unmeasured_confounders

Estimated prevalence unmeasured confounder exposed population unexposed_confounder_prev Numeric 0 1. Estimated prevalence unmeasured confounder unexposed population confounder_outcome_effect Numeric positive value. Estimated relationship unmeasured confounder outcome verbose Logical. Indicates whether print informative message. Default: TRUE or_correction Logical. Indicates whether use correction factor. methods used function based relative risks. rare outcomes, odds ratio approximates relative risk. common outcomes, correction factor needed. common outcome (>15%), set TRUE. Default: FALSE.

title: tipr 1.0.0
text: Breaking changes. names several arguments changed increased clarity: effect -> effect_observed outcome_association -> confounder_outcome_effect smd -> exposure_confounder_effect exposed_p -> exposed_confounder_prev unexposed_p -> exposed_confounder_prev exposure_r2 -> confounder_exposure_r2 outcome_r2 -> confounder_outcome_r2 Added two new example datasets: exdata_continuous exdata_rr

title: tipr 0.4.2
text: Make output tibble names consistent (adjusted_effect -> effect_adjusted)

title: tipr 0.4.1
text: CRAN release: 2022-05-05 Add additional functions specify *_with_continuous() (long form , function names, default unmeasured confounder Normally distributed) Change tip_lm() tip_coef().

title: tipr 0.4.0
text: CRAN release: 2022-04-16 Changed name lm_tip() tip_lm() API fundamentally updated functions now take numeric value first argument rather data frame. Added adjust_* functions allow specification unmeasured confounder qualities without tipping Split tip_* functions hazard ratio, odds ratio, relative risk Add R2 parameterization tip_coef_with_r2(), adjust_coef_with_r2(), r_value()

title: tipr 0.3.0
text: CRAN release: 2021-09-10 Added ability perform sensitivity analyses linear models via lm_tip()

title: tipr 0.2.0
text: CRAN release: 2020-11-16 Updated several function parameter names. main functions now tip() tip_with_binary(). parameter names self-explanatory. API fundamentally updated functions now take data frame first argument. now explicit (required) integration broom package.
